verses.text: This is what the LORD says: 'I will stir up a destructive wind against Babylon and against those who dwell in Leb Kamai.
verses.comment: The phrase 'Leb Kamai' is generally taken to mean 'the heart of those who rise up against Me,' a cryptic name for Chaldea. This sets up the prophecy against Babylon, showing God's direct intervention.

verses.text: I will send foreigners to Babylon, who will winnow her and empty her land; for in the day of disaster they will be against her from every side.
verses.comment: The image of winnowing highlights judgment and separation, which points forward to Christ's use of this imagery in Matt. 3:12, showing God's sovereignty in separating the faithful.

verses.text: Do not let the archer bend his bow, nor let him put on his armor. Do not spare her young men; completely destroy all her army.
verses.comment: Babylon is to suffer total defeat; total destruction is decreed, reminiscent of divine justice throughout Scripture. The uncompromising nature of God's judgment serves to highlight His holiness.

verses.text: In the land of the Chaldeans, the slain will fall, those who are pierced through in her streets.
verses.comment: The aftermath of judgment is vivid—there will be death in public places. This is a sign of God's justice being manifest openly.

verses.text: For neither Israel nor Judah has been forsaken by their God, by the LORD of hosts, though their land was full of guilt against the Holy One of Israel.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to Israel and Judah remains even in punishment. The title 'Holy One of Israel' links to Christological themes, affirming God's holiness and continued relationship despite Israel's sins.

verses.text: Flee from Babylon! Each one save his life! Do not be destroyed because of her guilt. For this is the time of the LORD’s vengeance; He will repay her what she deserves.
verses.comment: The call to escape connects to prophetic calls for holiness and separation. See Revelation 18:4, where similar language relates to the Church’s call to purity.

verses.text: Babylon was a golden cup in the LORD’s hand, making all the earth drunk. The nations drank her wine; therefore they have gone mad.
verses.comment: Babylon’s influence spreads corruption. The 'golden cup' imagery links to Revelation and ties to the spiritual consequences of worldly allure, reminiscent of figures of spiritual danger in the New Testament.

verses.text: Suddenly Babylon has fallen and been broken. Wail for her! Take balm for her pain; perhaps she may be healed.
verses.comment: Babylon’s fall is sudden and complete. The request for balm recalls the limited nature of human remedies versus divine justice.

verses.text: We would have healed Babylon, but she cannot be healed. Forsake her, and let us each go to our own country, for her judgment reaches up to heaven and rises to the skies.
verses.comment: The impossibility of healing Babylon shows the penalty for stubborn rebellion. This should stir a sense of humility in us and a need for sacramental reconciliation.

verses.text: The LORD has brought forth our vindication; come, let us declare in Zion the work of the LORD our God.
verses.comment: Vindication in Zion connects to the gathering of believers. It signals God’s action in salvation history leading toward a unified Church.

verses.text: Sharpen the arrows! Take up the shields! The LORD has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes, because His purpose concerning Babylon is to destroy it; for that is the vengeance of the LORD, the vengeance for His temple.
verses.comment: The Medes are divinely appointed for judgment because of Babylon’s desecration of the temple—God’s dwelling among His people. This foreshadows God’s zealous protection of worship.

verses.text: Set up a standard against the walls of Babylon; strengthen the guard, station the watchmen, prepare the ambushes, for the LORD has both planned and accomplished what He spoke against the inhabitants of Babylon.
verses.comment: The precision of divine intervention reveals that God’s will is sovereign and unstoppable, just as Christ later fulfills prophecy by His own divine authority.

verses.text: O you who dwell by many waters, rich in treasures, your end has come, the measure of your covetousness.
verses.comment: Babylon’s association with water and wealth recalls future judgment motifs, like the fate of the harlot in Revelation, showing worldly riches cannot save from God's justice.

verses.text: The LORD of hosts has sworn by Himself: Surely I will fill you with men, as with locusts, and they will raise a shout of victory over you.
verses.comment: Locusts symbolize overwhelming numbers of invaders, a divine reversal for Babylon. The LORD swears by Himself, emphasizing the absolute certainty of His judgment.

verses.text: He made the earth by His power; He established the world by His wisdom and stretched out the heavens by His understanding.
verses.comment: This creation formula points to God’s role as Creator, reflected in John 1:3 where Christ is affirmed as the divine agent in creation.

verses.text: When He utters His voice, there is a tumult of waters in the heavens, and He causes the clouds to rise from the ends of the earth; He makes lightning for the rain and brings out the wind from His storehouses.
verses.comment: God’s command over nature displays His absolute dominion, a mark of His divine power.

verses.text: Every man is stupid and without knowledge; every goldsmith is put to shame by his idols, for his images are false and there is no breath in them.
verses.comment: Idolatry is revealed to be utterly foolish; true wisdom is found in worship of the living God, who breathes life.

verses.text: They are worthless, a work of delusion; at the time of their judgment they will perish.
verses.comment: Images and idols cannot withstand God’s judgment, affirming that true worship is spiritual, as Christ taught (John 4:23-24).

verses.text: The portion of Jacob is not like these, for He is the one who formed all things, and Israel is the tribe of His inheritance; the LORD of hosts is His name.
verses.comment: Jacob’s portion indicates the intimate relationship between God and His chosen people—a precursor to the Church as God’s inheritance.

verses.text: You are My battle axe and weapon of war: with you I shatter nations; with you I destroy kingdoms;
verses.comment: Israel—and ultimately, the faithful—are the Lord’s instrument for carrying out His purposes, revealing a spiritual participation in divine judgment.

verses.text: With you I shatter the horse and its rider; with you I shatter the chariot and its driver.
verses.comment: The language evokes the Exodus, where the LORD triumphs over oppressors, continuing the theme of divine deliverance.

verses.text: With you I shatter man and woman; with you I shatter old man and youth; with you I shatter young man and maiden;
verses.comment: Judgment is all-encompassing, touching every demographic. God's justice is impartial and complete.

verses.text: With you I shatter shepherd and flock; with you I shatter farmer and his team; with you I shatter governors and officials.
verses.comment: No sphere of influence is exempt from judgment, underscoring total accountability before God.

verses.text: I will repay Babylon and all the inhabitants of Chaldea for all their evil that they have done in Zion before your eyes,' declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s covenant justice is reciprocal; Babylon receives judgment for its sins against Zion, foreshadowing how the Church will ultimately be vindicated by the justice of God.

verses.text: 'Behold, I am against you, O destroying mountain, declares the LORD, which destroys the whole earth; I will stretch out My hand against you, and roll you down from the rocks, and make you a burned mountain.
verses.comment: Babylon is described as a destructive mountain—judged and burned by God. The mountain imagery is used in Revelation as a figure of final judgment.

verses.text: No stone shall be taken from you for a cornerstone, nor for a foundation, but you shall be desolate forever, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Denied the dignity of cornerstone status, Babylon contrasts with Christ, the true cornerstone of God’s spiritual temple (see Ps. 118:22; Matt. 21:42).

verses.text: Set up a standard in the land; blow the trumpet among the nations; prepare the nations for battle against her, summon the kingdoms against her: Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Appoint a commander against her; bring up horses like a swarm of locusts.
verses.comment: The summoning of nations under God’s command signifies collective judgment, where all powers are subject to Him.

verses.text: Prepare the nations for battle against her, the kings of the Medes, with their governors and all their officials—every land under their dominion.
verses.comment: God directs nations and leaders for His appointed purposes, further underlining God’s sovereignty even over political entities.

verses.text: The land trembles and writhes, for the LORD’s purposes against Babylon stand—to make Babylon a desolation, without inhabitant.
verses.comment: The irreversible nature of God’s decree is clear—a complete and final desolation, reminiscent of the end of worldly kingdoms in Revelation.

verses.text: The warriors of Babylon have ceased fighting, remain in their strongholds; their strength has failed, they have become like women. Her dwelling places are set on fire; her bars are broken.
verses.comment: Babylon’s once-mighty defenders are rendered powerless—hinting at the futility of trusting in human power alone.

verses.text: One runner runs to meet another, and one messenger to meet another, to tell the king of Babylon that his city has been taken on every side;
verses.comment: The collapse is so sudden that frantic messengers must be dispatched—a sign of God’s swift judgment.

verses.text: The passages are seized, the riverbanks are set on fire, and the men of war are terrified.
verses.comment: All defenses are undone—earthly security is shown to be fleeting in the face of God’s judgment.

verses.text: For thus says the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel: 'The daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor at the time it is trampled; yet a little while and the harvest time will come for her.'
verses.comment: Harvest imagery points to the coming time of judgment, a motif used by Christ for final separation between righteous and wicked (Matt. 13:30, 39).

verses.text: 'Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon has devoured me, crushed me; he has made me an empty vessel, he has swallowed me like a monster, filled his belly with my delicacies, and spit me out.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar's treatment of Zion is described as brutal and consuming—a metaphor for how worldly powers abuse the elect, later redeemed through God's intervention.

verses.text: Let the violence done to me and to my flesh be upon Babylon,' says the inhabitant of Zion; 'and let my blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldea,' says Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This is an appeal for vindication against oppression, a cry answered ultimately in the New Testament by the promise of justice through Christ and His Church.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the LORD: 'Behold, I will plead your cause and take vengeance for you. I will dry up her sea and make her springs dry.'
verses.comment: God's personal advocacy for His people points to His intimate connection with His Church, and use of drying up waters as judgment recalls pivotal saving acts.

verses.text: Babylon shall become a heap of ruins, a dwelling for jackals, a horror and a hissing, without inhabitant.
verses.comment: The desolation of Babylon is total, confirming God’s absolute authority over human pride and power.

verses.text: They roar together like lions, they growl like lion cubs.
verses.comment: Babylon’s enemies are described as fierce; the image shows intensity of divine judgment.

verses.text: When they are inflamed, I will prepare their banquet and make them drunk, that they may shout with joy and then sleep a perpetual sleep and not wake up, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Divine retribution includes giving Babylon over to delusion and final destruction.

verses.text: I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter, like rams and male goats.
verses.comment: Use of sacrificial imagery foreshadows the ultimate Lamb, Christ, whose sacrifice brings final victory over evil.

verses.text: How Sheshak is taken, the pride of the whole earth seized! How Babylon has become a horror among the nations!
verses.comment: Sheshak is a cryptic name for Babylon, emphasizing the shock and fear caused by her fall.

verses.text: The sea has come up over Babylon; she is covered with the multitude of its waves.
verses.comment: The sea’s imagery recalls overwhelming judgment and is consistent with New Testament use for chaotic powers opposed to God.

verses.text: Her cities have become a desolation, a dry land and a desert, a land where no man dwells and through which no one passes.
verses.comment: Judgment brings total destruction; themes of desolation are echoed by Christ regarding rejection of the gospel (Matt. 23:38).

verses.text: I will punish Bel in Babylon, and make him spit out what he has swallowed. The nations shall no longer stream to him, and the wall of Babylon shall fall.
verses.comment: Bel, chief deity of Babylon, is vanquished—true worship is reserved for the LORD. The fall of the wall symbolizes the collapse of all false systems.

verses.text: Go out from her, My people! Save your lives, each of you, from the fierce anger of the LORD.
verses.comment: Call to leave Babylon to avoid judgment. This has spiritual application as a warning to flee from sin and false worship.

verses.text: Do not lose heart or be afraid at the rumor heard in the land; when one rumor comes one year and then another the next, violence in the land, and ruler against ruler.
verses.comment: Themes of chaos and rumors connect to Jesus' teachings on perseverance in the face of trials.

verses.text: Therefore, behold, the days are coming when I will punish the idols of Babylon, and her whole land will be put to shame, and all her slain will fall in her midst.
verses.comment: God's active punishment of idolatry—the true worship of God supersedes all other objects of devotion.

verses.text: Then the heavens and the earth and all that is in them will sing for joy over Babylon, for destroyers will come against her from the north, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: All creation rejoices at the fall of evil, prefiguring universal rejoicing at the final victory of God.

verses.text: As Babylon has caused the slain of Israel to fall, so at Babylon the slain of all the earth will fall.
verses.comment: Reciprocal justice is enacted; Babylon becomes a symbol for all godless systems and their fate.

verses.text: You who have escaped the sword, go, do not stand still! Remember the LORD from afar, and let Jerusalem come into your mind.
verses.comment: Those who are saved are called to remember God's holy city—Jerusalem, which foreshadows the new Jerusalem in Revelation.

verses.text: We are ashamed, for we have heard reproach; disgrace covers our faces, for foreigners have come into the holy places of the LORD’s house.
verses.comment: Shame over the desecration of sacred places points forward to Christ’s zeal for purity in worship (John 2:17).

verses.text: Therefore, behold, the days are coming, declares the LORD, when I will punish her idols, and through all her land the wounded shall groan.
verses.comment: Continued focus on rooting out false worship: spiritual renewal depends on fidelity to God alone.

verses.text: Though Babylon should ascend to heaven, and though she fortify her high stronghold, destroyers will come from Me against her, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: No earthly defense avails against God; reminiscent of the Tower of Babel narrative, rejecting prideful ambition.

verses.text: A cry is heard from Babylon, great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans!
verses.comment: The intensity of Babylon’s fall contrasts the earlier arrogance—God humbles the proud.

verses.text: For the LORD is destroying Babylon and silencing her noisy voice. Their waves roar like great waters, the clamor of their voices resounds.
verses.comment: God's judgment is thorough, silencing worldly arrogance. True praise is directed toward God alone.

verses.text: For a destroyer has come upon her, upon Babylon. Her warriors are taken, their bows are broken in pieces; for the LORD is a God of recompense, He will surely repay.
verses.comment: Divine recompense is sure—a theme Christ echoes regarding final justice.

verses.text: I will make her officials and wise men drunk, her governors, her commanders, and warriors; they shall sleep a perpetual sleep and not wake up, declares the King, whose name is the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: The rulers are rendered powerless, a foreshadowing of God’s judgment against all forms of rebellion.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: The broad wall of Babylon shall be utterly broken, and her high gates shall be burned with fire. The peoples labor in vain, and the nations weary themselves only for fire.
verses.comment: Worldly achievements are shown to be meaningless before God, as indicated elsewhere in wisdom literature (Ecclesiastes).

verses.text: The word that Jeremiah the prophet commanded Seraiah son of Neriah, son of Mahseiah, when he went with Zedekiah king of Judah to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. Now Seraiah was the quartermaster.
verses.comment: This historical note shows Jeremiah’s careful documentation of God’s word, affirming the value of faithfully transmitting prophecy, later reflected in apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Jeremiah wrote in a book all the disaster that would come upon Babylon, all these words that are written concerning Babylon.
verses.comment: Written scripture preserves prophecy. This affirms the importance of divinely guided writing and transmission.

verses.text: And Jeremiah said to Seraiah: 'When you come to Babylon, see that you read all these words,
verses.comment: Public reading of scripture is commanded, prefiguring the liturgical reading tradition maintained within the Church.

verses.text: 'and say, 'O LORD, You have promised to destroy this place so that neither man nor beast shall live in it; it shall be desolate forever.'
verses.comment: The fulfillment of God’s promise of judgment is proclaimed aloud—encouraging trust in the reliability of prophecy.

verses.text: When you finish reading this book, tie a stone to it and throw it into the middle of the Euphrates,
verses.comment: Symbolic action: casting the scroll into the river emphasizes the certainty and irreversibility of Babylon's judgment. This act is later mirrored in Revelation.

verses.text: and say, 'Thus shall Babylon sink, and shall not rise from the disaster that I will bring upon her, and they shall become weary.' Thus far are the words of Jeremiah.
verses.comment: The chapter’s closing reinforces the completeness of God’s judgement and the authority of Jeremiah’s prophecy, foreshadowing scriptural fulfillment in the Church's mission.
